posts.footer: Hugh de Kretser, the director of the Human Rights Law Center, on reports that the Australian authorities paid a migrants smuggler to take his cargo to Indonesia, via The New York Times.

summaries.body: Australia is moving to ever more radical measures to avoid our international obligations. But the world is watching.

asset.embed_html: <iframe class="embedly-embed" src="//cdn.embedly.com/widgets/media.html?src=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.youtube.com%2Fembed%2FLo7EwqOQC4o%3Ffeature%3Doembed&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.youtube.com%2Fwatch%3Fv%3DLo7EwqOQC4o%26feature%3Dyoutu.be&image=https%3A%2F%2Fi.ytimg.com%2Fvi%2FLo7EwqOQC4o%2Fhqdefault.jpg&key=170aca4a25074a88942b11f27e7ca43f&type=text%2Fhtml&schema=youtube" width="854" height="480" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

summaries.body: Thomas Fuller on the particular quirk that persists from the days of Myanmar's authoritarian rule: The country remains obsessed with pristine dollar bills.

posts.footer: The Associated Press on Serge Atlaoui, who got a reprieve from execution in April, via Twitter

summaries.body: BREAKING: Indonesian court rejects final appeal of French national facing execution for drug offenses
North Korea canceled plans to attend the University Games in South Korea because of the planned opening of a United Nations human rights office in Seoul, South Korea reported.

posts.footer: A tweet by Tullian Tchividjian, a grandson of Billy Graham, who resigned from a megachurch in Florida after admitting he had an affair, via Twitter

summaries.body: Welcome to the valley of the shadow of death...thank God grace reigns here.
Europol, the European police agency, will track and block social media accounts linked to the Islamic State, many of which are used to recruit new members.

display_asset.caption: Tombstones of relatives of Zhou Yongkang, an official who was sentenced to life over graft. A new app and online platform let citizens to report suspected corruption.

summaries.body: China's Central Commission for Discipline Inspection is allowing users of it mobile app and online platform to report corruption and violations of party discipline.
Eight people were indicted on suspicion of selling millions of bottles of counterfeit 5-Hour Energy drinks that were intended to be sold in Mexico.

display_asset.credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times

summaries.body: The U.S. government crushed more than a ton of illegally poached ivory in Times Square, a display meant to signal a crackdown on the ivory market.
Neymar, the Brazilian soccer star, was suspended for four games for his part in a fracas at the end of a recent loss to Colombia and will miss the rest of the Copa America.
A state board revoked the license of a former U.S. Army doctor, finding that his "bizarre" training methods for troops was "abhorrent and abnormal."
Jason Day collapsed, apparently from a dizzy spell, on the final hole of his round at the U.S. Open. He finished the hole (with a bogey) after lying on the grass for several minutes.
Tiger Woods shot a six-over 76 in the second round of the U.S. Open, most likely ensuring that he will miss the cut for just the fifth time as a professional.
Prosecutors rested their case in the trial of James E. Holmes, who is charged with killing 12 people in a Colorado theater in 2012, after an emotional final witness.
The Texas Supreme Court upheld a divorce granted in a lower court for a same-sex couple, a precedent-setting decision in a state with a same-sex marriage ban.
The Philae spacecraft that landed on a speeding comet last fall made contact again after a five-day gap, the European Space Agency said. It awoke this week after seven months.
Oakland hosted a parade for the N.B.A. champion Golden State Warriors. Above, Stephen Curry acknowledges the crowd.
Rand Paul appointed Mark Spitznagel, the hedge fund manager, as a senior economic adviser as Mr. Paul seeks the Republican presidential nomination.
Children as young as 3 have a sense of justice and are sensitive to the harm of others, preferring to help victims than punish perpetrators, scientists found.
Google said it will create a process that will allow victims of "revenge porn" to request removal of those images from the search engine.

display_asset.caption: Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida spoke at the Faith and Freedom Coalition's Road to Majority Conference in Washington on Friday.

summaries.body: Jeb Bush told a gathering of religious conservatives that the fight over same-sex marriage should continue regardless of what the Supreme Court decides in a coming case.
Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece joined President Vladimir V. Putin at an economic forum in Russia, a visit seen as an effort to pressure Europe’s leaders in debt talks.
A hospital in Thailand known for treating medical tourists said it quarantined 58 staff members after authorities confirmed its first case of MERS.
Retirement communities in Florida are expected to show the most economic growth in America in 2016, replacing oil towns, a new report on urban areas said.

posts.footer: The Associated Press | The New York Times

summaries.body: The Obama administration unveiled rules intended to improve fuel efficiency for medium-size and heavy-duty trucks and to cut pollution blamed for global warming.
Toyota in Japan is defending its diversity initiative after Julie Hamp, the first foreign executive to work for the company there, was arrested for illegally bringing a painkiller into Japan.
Extremists in Afghanistan, Iraq and Nigeria were mostly responsible for a nearly 35 percent rise in the number of terrorist attacks in 2014, a State Department report said.

display_asset.caption: A fisherman holding an endangered vaquita porpoise that was caught in a gill net for sharks and other fish in the Gulf of Mexico.

summaries.body: The world’s most endangered porpoise is disappearing faster than previously believed, threatened by gill-fishing nets in the Gulf of California, a new report said.
Mo Farah, the distance runner and two-time Olympic champion, said he had never taken performance-enhancing drugs and described two missed tests as "simple mistakes."
Jon Stewart of "The Daily Show" avoided jokes in his monologue Thursday. Instead, he spoke of the Charleston shooting, including the reluctance of some to call it a terrorist attack.
Britain is investigating whether a man found dead on a roof was a stowaway who fell from a plane. A second person suspected of being a stowaway was found alive on a flight.
Ten Tunisian diplomats seized by Libyan gunmen last week have been released, Tunisia's foreign minister said, while denying they had been traded for a Libyan militia leader.
The U.N. said $1.6 billion in aid is needed for Yemen, where about 21 million people are struggling to find food and shelter after Saudi-led airstrikes against Houthi fighters.
North Korea said it had succeeded where the top minds in science have failed, state news media reported, developing a drug that can cure MERS, Ebola, SARS and AIDS.
A cruise ship crashed into a wall in the Eisenhower Lock in upstate New York on Thursday night, the Coast Guard said, injuring more than a dozen passengers.

posts.footer: A Times correspondent, on efforts to reach a deal on an international bailout for Greece, via Twitter

summaries.body: ECB Council to hold midday teleconference on request for more emergency assistance to Greek banks after #eurogroup deadlocks, again. @ecb
Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan, which has hanged more than 170 people since December, ordered a halt to executions for Ramadan.

posts.footer: Le Monde, the influential French newspaper, in an English-language editorial

summaries.body: Today, we solemnly say to our friends across the Channel: beware, Brexit could be your Waterloo!
Danish voters ousted their center-left government in a clear swing to the right that unexpectedly elevated an anti-immigrant, anti-European Union party.
Vietnam, whose tourism industry is flagging, said visitors from five European countries could enter without a visa.
Julie Gayet has appeared for the first time at an official ceremony with President François Hollande, amid reports that she is gradually becoming France’s first lady.
At least 25 people died after drinking toxic liquor in suburban Mumbai, India, the police said.

posts.footer: A Times correspondent in Southeast Asia on Burmese money changers' curious reluctance to accept U.S. bills with the merest crease or tear, via Twitter

summaries.body: Myanmar's Obsession With Clean Cash: the bane of visitors. NYT video from Yangon: https://t.co/osa4yq4nqF
Thailand cautioned transgender migrant workers against public cross-dressing in the Middle East, after two Thais in the United Arab Emirates were said to have been detained.
The Federal Communications Commission voted to explore subsidizing broadband Internet access for poor Americans.

posts.footer: Zhanna Nemtsova, whose father, the opposition figure Boris Y. Nemtsov, was killed in Moscow in February, and who blames the Russian media in part for his death, via The Guardian

summaries.body: Many of the articles printed by the Kremlin-controlled media ape the divisive rhetoric of Rwanda before the genocide.

posts.footer: The South China Morning Post | The New York Times

summaries.body: A prominent Hong Kong lawmaker wept during a radio appearance over her failure to vote for Beijing's election plan for the city due to a parliamentary blunder.

display_asset.caption: Dogs at a slaughterhouse in Yulin.
display_asset.credit: Humane Society International, via Associated Press

summaries.body: As the Chinese city of Yulin prepares for its annual dog meat festival this weekend, one analyst says that conflict between protesters and meat traders is "unavoidable."
Peter Humphrey, a British investigator recently freed from a Chinese prison and deported, said his jailers withheld medical care in the hope that he would sign a confession.
A South Korean health official said the country's outbreak of Middle East respiratory syndrome appeared to have "leveled off," with just one new case reported on Friday.
The U.N. aviation agency said Thailand was providing insufficient oversight of its airlines' safety practices.

display_asset.caption: Jill Alikas St. Thomas, founder of the Mad Hatter Coffee and Tea Company, brought her wares to the Cannabis World Congress and Business Exposition.
display_asset.credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times

summaries.body: How do you show off your wares in a place where using them would be illegal? At a cannabis trade show in New York City, vendors treaded a careful line.
Cuba is poised to introduce about three dozen Wi-Fi hot spots and reduce steep fees for getting online amid new pressures to increase Internet access.

display_asset.caption: A group of Iraqis who were detained Thursday by the Hungarian police after illegally crossing the border from Serbia. Hungary is planning to build a fence along the border.

summaries.body: Hungary has drawn international condemnation for its government's plans to erect a fence along the Serbian border to keep out migrants. Above, detained Iraqis.
The Cty Council in Spokane, Wash., voted 6-0 to remove Rachel Dolezal, the former leader of the N.A.A.C.P. branch, from the city's police ombudsman commission.
Texas executed Gregory Russeau, 45, who was convicted of killing a 75-year-old auto mechanic in a 2001 robbery. He received a lethal injection.
U.S. agencies that build civilian rockets and nuclear arms agreed to work together on planetary defense, with the goal of learning how to deflect potential comets and asteroids.
Florida is moving toward allowing commercial activities in state parks, including a plan to sell cattle-grazing rights in the Myakka River State Park, according to documents.
Senator Bernie Sanders sought to burnish his populist credentials as he introduced a bill to protect the pensions of millions of retirees from the threat of deep cuts.
Federal regulators are implementing strict new rules on unwanted telemarketing calls and text messages and giving Americans more ways to refuse them.
The Supreme Court ruled that a death row inmate was entitled to a hearing to determine whether he is intellectually disabled, and so may not be executed.
This year, Earth has experienced its warmest May, spring (March to May) and first five months on record, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said.
Pablo Sandoval of the Boston Red Sox was benched for Thursday's game after he checked Instagram and liked photos during the seventh inning Wednesday.
A lawsuit claiming that Justin Bieber and Usher stole the song "Somebody to Love" from two writers in Virginia will go forward, three appellate judges ruled.
Ban Ki-moon, the U.N. secretary general, criticized Israel for the deaths of at least 561 children, most of them Palestinian, during last summer's conflict in Gaza.
The judge in the Aurora theater shooting trial said he would let jurors see a photo of the youngest victim, Veronica Moser-Sullivan, 6, on Friday, but for only three seconds.
One of the footballs from last season's A.F.C. championship game — the one that got New England penalized for deflating balls — will be auctioned for at least $25,000.
Jeralean Talley, the oldest known person in the world, died at age 116 on Wednesday at home in Inkster, Mich. Born in 1899 in Georgia, she bowled until she was 104.
A former University of Mississippi student pleaded guilty to a charge stemming from placing a noose on a statue of James Meredith, the college's first black student, last year.
Khairullozhon Matanov, who treated the Tsarnaev brothers to dinner after the Boston Marathon bombing, was given 30 months in prison for misleading investigators.
Matthew Apperson, who is accused of shooting at George Zimmerman during a traffic confrontation last month, now faces an attempted murder charge.
Fans in Chicago celebrated the Blackhawks' third Stanley Cup in six years with a parade and rally on Thursday. Above, Patrick Kane holds up the trophy.
The U.S. Justice Department charged 243 people, including 46 doctors and other medical professionals, with scams that defrauded the Medicare system of $712 million.
A 1,500-acre wildfire in California's San Bernardino National Forest, only 5 percent contained, forced five summer camps to evacuate.

posts.footer: The Associated Press | The Boston Globe

summaries.body: Forty-eight members and associates of the Columbia Point Dawgs, Boston's largest and most powerful gang, were indicted on drug and gun charges, federal authorities said.
Thailand confirmed its first case of the MERS virus, becoming the fourth Asian country to register the virus this year. A 75-year-old businessman tested positive for it.
Richard B. Zabel, the deputy United States attorney in Manhattan under Preet Bharara, is stepping down to become general counsel at one of Wall Street’s biggest hedge funds.
Shares of Fitbit soared in their trading debut, opening at $30.40 on Thursday — up 52 percent from the I.P.O. price of $20. Above, James Park, a co-founder of Fitbit.

posts.footer: The Times reporter covers the Supreme Court, via Twitter

summaries.body: Supreme Court allows Texas to reject specialty license plates bearing confederate flag, 5-4, with Justice Thomas joining liberals.
A German billionaire’s son who was abducted on Wednesday was released without payment of a multimillion-euro ransom that had been demanded, an official said.
An Australian judge barred a mother from breastfeeding because she had gotten a tattoo, saying her negative H.I.V. and hepatitis tests were not conclusive.
Somali security forces thwarted an attack on a political conference, killing three gunmen and the driver of a car rigged with explosives, a police officer said.
An arrest warrant was issued in Australia for a doctor, believed to be in Syria, who appeared in an Islamic State recruitment video.
South Korean lawmakers approved a new prime minister, weeks after the last one stepped down over allegations that he had accepted illegal campaign donations.
Chinese companies that build civilian ships will be required to ensure that the military can use them in an emergency, a state-run newspaper reported.

posts.footer: A reporter for the Post and Courier in Charleston, S.C., where the police reported that a shooting had taken place in a downtown church, via Twitter

summaries.body: Dramatic pic by @MatthewFortner of search for gunman in downtown Charleston. #chsnews http://t.co/h7vFO5sVK3
A drug for dwarfism improved growth in children by a significant amount in a preliminary study, its developer said. No treatment for the condition has ever been approved.
A military jury found a Marine sergeant guilty of murder in the retrial of a major Iraq war-crimes case involving the 2006 killing of an Iraqi man.
Fitbit, the fitness-tracking device maker, priced its I.P.O. at $20 a share, valuing the company at $4.1 billion.
The mayor of Spokane, Wash., called for Rachel Dolezal, the former N.A.A.C.P. leader, and two others to resign from the city’s Office of the Police Ombudsman commission.
Foster Farms, a chicken plant in California, suspended five workers after a graphic video purporting to show inhumane slaughter practices was released.
A California judge said Ellen Pao, a former partner at Kleiner Perkins, owes the venture capital firm $276,000 in legal costs related to her unsuccessful discrimination lawsuit.
Airbnb, the housing rental service, is in talks to raise $1 billion in venture capital, a person close to the discussions said. The financing round would value it at $24 billion.
The number of new H.I.V. cases in a rural Indiana county that has seen a recent epidemic has fallen drastically, public health officials said.
Apple's new streaming music service, set to arrive on June 30, has already upset independent record companies because of its proposed licensing terms.
The N.B.A. finals averaged 19.94 million viewers, the most-watched series since 1998, Michael Jordan's last season with the Chicago Bulls.
Melissa Rivers, right, will co-host "Fashion Police," the E! show hosted by her mother, Joan Rivers, until she died last year.
Officials ordered the inspection of ventilation systems in train tunnels nationwide after a smoke-filled tunnel in Washington caused a passenger's death in January.
Muse, the arena-filling British band, topped the Billboard album chart for the first time with its new album, "Drones."
A time capsule placed by Paul Revere and Samuel Adams in 1795, added to in 1855 and found last year was returned to the Massachusetts Statehouse with new tokens.
